rsbNotes.title: Josh 22–24
rsbNotes.text: 22:1–24:33 The book closes with three chapters about Israel’s faithfulness, following God’s faithfulness that has been the main subject so far (21:43–45 and note). The human response demanded by God’s remarkable grace is the recurring theme of the final chapters. Each chapter begins with Joshua summoning the people (22:1; 23:1–2; 24:1), and focuses on the faithfulness God now requires of them.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:23
rsbNotes.text:
22:23 building an altar. Both groups accept the teaching of passages such as Lev. 17:8, 9 and Deut. 12 (v. 16 note).

offerings. See Lev. 1–3.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:25
rsbNotes.text:
22:25 a boundary between us and you. The Book of Joshua has repeatedly rejected disunity (v. 16 note).

no portion in the Lord. To deny that their land was God’s land (v. 19) was to deny that they shared in God’s promise.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:27
rsbNotes.text: 22:27 witness. The altar was to function as a testimony (cf. the stones at Gilgal, 4:20–24), not a place of sacrifice.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:30
rsbNotes.text: 22:30 good in their eyes. Contrast Phinehas’s reaction to actual apostasy in Num. 25:7–8.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:31
rsbNotes.text:
22:31 the Lord is in our midst. The fears of v. 18 would not be realized because the suspected unfaithfulness had not occurred.

you have delivered. This is an unusual way of making an important point: by not turning from God they had saved Israel from God’s wrath.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 22:34
rsbNotes.text: 22:34 Witness. The altar witnessed (v. 27) to the one reality that united all Israel and, by implication, to the offense that could destroy Israel (v. 16).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23
rsbNotes.text: 23:1–16 Joshua in his old age addresses all Israel, probably at Shiloh (18:1; 19:51; 21:2). Chs. 23 and 24 take up the exhortations of ch. 1 and apply them to Israel following the substantial fulfillment of God’s promises. The beginning and end of the book (chs. 1 and 23–24) convey the purpose of the whole, namely, an exhortation to faithful obedience based on the complete faithfulness of God to His promises. Joshua’s speech in ch. 23 expresses this three times over (vv. 3–8, 9–13, 14–16), with variations in emphasis.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:1
rsbNotes.text:
23:1 rest. See note 1:13. The experience of “rest . . . from all their surrounding enemies,” here incompletely realized, will become part of Israel’s hope (Deut. 12:10; 2 Sam. 7:11; 1 Chr. 22:9; cf. Mic. 5:9; Luke 1:71).

enemies. Israel represents God’s kingship to the world (Ex. 19:5–6) and will ultimately bring blessing to the nations (Gen. 12:3). The nations’ hostility to Israel is an expression of their hostility to God (cf. Gen. 3:15; Ex. 23:22 notes).

old. Joshua died at the age of 110 (24:29 note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:2
rsbNotes.text: 23:2 all Israel. He called representatives of every tribe.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:3–8
rsbNotes.text: 23:3–8 In these verses the call to obedience is introduced by a reminder of God’s faithfulness (vv. 5, 9, 14).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:3
rsbNotes.text: 23:3 God . . . fought for you. See note 10:14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:4
rsbNotes.text:
23:4 nations that remain. Affirmation of the complete faithfulness of God to His promises and the incompleteness of the actual conquest stand side by side in this chapter (21:45 note).

inheritance. See note 1:6.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:6
rsbNotes.text:
23:6 be very strong. The consequences of God’s promises applied to Joshua in 1:6 (note) are now applied to all Israel.

and to do. See note 1:7.

Book of the Law. See note 1:8.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:7
rsbNotes.text: 23:7 that you may not mix with these nations. The Hebrew makes a close connection between vv. 6 and 7. Faithful obedience to the Book of the Law will avoid religious association with the pagan nations.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:8
rsbNotes.text:
23:8 cling to. See note 22:5.

as you have done. The previous generation who rebelled in the wilderness and the generations to follow did not do as well (cf. 24:31).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:9
rsbNotes.text: 23:9 no man has been able to stand before you. The promise to Joshua in 1:5 has been fulfilled for the Israelites (Deut. 7:24; 11:25).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:11
rsbNotes.text: 23:11 love the Lord your God. In the Bible love can be commanded. This does not mean that such love lacks emotional depth. It is actually more than emotion. It is expressed in glad and willing obedience (22:5 note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:12
rsbNotes.text:
23:12 turn back. See 22:16 and note.

make marriages with them. See notes Gen. 26:34, 35; 34:1–31; 38:1–30.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:13
rsbNotes.text: 23:13 God will no longer drive out. The validity of God’s promise (v. 5) is not dependent on human cooperation. The history of Israel shows this, as does the rest of the Bible, culminating in the work of Christ. But the promise will not benefit those who reject the grace of God. This provision was part of the promise from the beginning (Gen. 12:3).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:14–16
rsbNotes.text: 23:14–16 See note on vv. 3–8. In this final section of Joshua’s speech the exhortation is again based on a reminder of God’s faithfulness, but consists entirely of warnings of the consequences of turning away from the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:14
rsbNotes.text:
23:14 know in your hearts and souls. Knowledge of God’s faithfulness can never be merely intellectual, but pervades and shapes every aspect of a person’s life.

not one word has failed. See note 21:45.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:15
rsbNotes.text: 23:15 good things . . . evil things. There are two sides to God’s faithfulness, because there are two sides to His covenant: promises and warnings. God can be trusted to enforce the warnings as fully as He can be trusted to keep His promises.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 23:16
rsbNotes.text:
23:16 transgress the covenant. See note 7:11.

anger. See note 7:1.
